tldr:
Many machine learning models trained using gradient methods exhibit a non-trivial characteristic: models trained from different random initializations become functionally equivalent, even though their parameter representations differ. This phenomenon, Linear Mode Connectivity (LMC), is crucial for the success of non-convex optimization and practical parameter-based operations such as model merging. While LMC has been achieved for neural networks, its attainment for other models remains an open question.
This paper addresses this gap by focusing on soft tree ensembles, commonly used differentiable tree-based models. The authors demonstrate that achieving LMC in soft tree ensembles requires not only tree permutation invariance, which exists in neural networks, but also two additional invariances: subtree flip invariance and splitting order invariance. These invariances are unique to tree architectures.  Furthermore, they show that by designing a decision list-based tree architecture, LMC can be achieved even without these additional invariances.
